elements.text: PART ONE
1. EXT. WOODLAND. DUSK
(FX: WOODLAND SOUNDS — RUSTLE OF WIND IN LEAVES; HOOT OF AN
OWL. FADE UP TARDIS MATERIALISATION. DOOR OPENS)
(BREATHES DEEPLY, THEN SIGHS IN SATISFACTION) And was Jerusalem builded here...
I’m sorry, I don’t understand the reference. (REALISING) Oh, you mean we’re on Earth? Again.
England, to be precise.
(FX: RUSTLING OF AUTUMN LEAVES AS THE DOCTOR SCOOPS SOME FROM THE GROUND)
(EXPERIMENTAL SNIFF) Smell that leaf mould, Nyssa.
I’d rather not, if you don’t mind.
(SNIFFS AGAIN) Somewhere in Suffolk, unless I’m much mistaken. (ANOTHER SNIFF) Late October, I’d say...
Now you’re showing off.
Winter in New York. Springtime in Paris. Summer in Venice. And autumn in Suffolk... Nothing quite like it.
(SHIVERS) It’s chilly. And it’s getting dark.
FX: OFF/DISTANT — THE TRUMPETING OF AN ELEPHANT
That can’t be right. It sounded like the call of a Loxodonta
Africana.
A what?
African Bush elephant.
MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 3
Africa? I thought you said we were in Suffolk.
So we are. (MUSING) We must be near a zoo. Whipsnade? No, that would put us closer to Dunstable. (ROUSING HIMSELF) Come on, Nyssa!
Where?
Let’s find out where we are.
Do we have to, Doctor? Couldn’t we just go somewhere a little more... appealing?

More appealing than Suffolk? In the chilly autumn dusk? Impossible! Besides, there’s the mystery of the misplaced elephant to solve. We can’t possibly leave until we’ve got to the bottom of that, can we?
Can’t we?
MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 4
2. EXT. WOODLAND. DUSK. A LITTLE LATER
(FX: CRUNCH, CRACK, RUSTLE OF UNDERGROWTH AS THE DOCTOR AND
FORCE THEIR WAY THROUGH)
Watch out for the brambles, Nyssa, they can be rather — (CUT) — ow!
FX: BOTH STOP
Admit it, Doctor. We’re lost.
(NURSING CUT) Nonsense. Oww!
Then where are we?
(PREVARICATING) One can only said to be lost if one had a destination in mind in the first place.
All right. Which direction is the TARDIS?
Well, it’s... back there somewhere.
(FX: A BRIEF COMMOTION IN THE BUSHES — THEY SHAKE AND RUSTLE. UNBEKNOWNST TO THE DOCTOR AND NYSSA THEY’RE BEING STALKED BY A LION)
What was that?
Just some woodland creature going about its nocturnal
business.
It sounded quite... big, though, didn’t it?
Probably a fox or a badger. A deer even.
FX: MORE RUSTLING. FOLLOWED BY A LOW, RUMBLING GROWL
(THOUGHTFULLY) Or possibly not...
MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 5
(NERVOUSLY) Doctor?
Let’s keep moving. This way, I think. (FX: FOOTSTEPS CRUNCHING ON LEAVES, UNDERGROWTH RUSTLING AS THEY PUSH THROUGH) Yes, look. There’s a road beyond that line of trees ahead. —
FX: OFF: STEALTHIER RUSTLING; ANOTHER SOFT GROWL
(MOVING ON, SOTTO) Whatever that thing is, it’s stalking us.
(MOVING ON) Brave heart, Nyssa. I think there’s a parhway on the other side of these — (SNAGGED AGAIN) — ow!
(FX: FROM OFF, APPROACHING RATTLE AND CLATTER OF A HORSE-DRAWN CARRIAGE)
You’re right, that sounds like a carriage!
That could be our salvation. Quickly now — (EFFORT AS HE
THROUGH THE LAST BIT OF UNDERGROWTH WITH A CRACKLE)
FX: RATTLE AND CLATTER OF THE CARRIAGE IS MUCH CLOSER NOW
Have they seen us?
They soon will. (RAISES VOICE) Hello there!
(FX: SUDDEN THRASH OF UNDERGROWTH FOLLOWED BY AN EAR-SPLITTING ROAR)
(SCREAMS) Doctor!
Good grief, it’s a lion! What a beauty!
FX: LION ROARS AGAIN
It’s between us and the carriage!
Stand perfectly still, Nyssa. Show no fear. Stare it down.
MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 6
(OFF, PULLING UP HORSES) Whoa there!
FX: CARRIAGE CLATTERS TO A STOP. LION SNARLS
I don’t think it’s going to work, Doctor.
Have faith, Nyssa. I usually get on very well with cats.
FX: THE LION LETS OUT AN ATTACK ROAR
No!!!
(FX: THE WHISTLE-THUNK OF AN ARROW FLYING THROUGH THE AIR AND
HOME. LION’S ROAR IS ABRUPTLY CUT OFF WITH A YELP OF PAIN AND WE HEAR THE HEAVY THUD OF ITS BODY AS IT DROPS TO THE
(SADLY) Oh. Poor, noble beast.
(OFF/APPROACHING) Are you unharmed?
Not a hair out of place, thanks to you. That was quite a shot.
My father taught me to use the bow when I still barely had strength to pull back the arrow. In my tribe we are hunters before we can walk.
And fine ones too, from the looks of it.
I didn’t realise there were hunting tribes in England.
Oh, our friend here is a long way from home, Nyssa. Despite the dinner suit, he’s a Sioux warrior, if I’m not mistaken.
(SURPRISED) You know of my tribe?
I’ve had one or two encounters. A proud, noble people. They do wonders with chokecherries, wild turnips and buffalo liver, as I remember.
MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 7
So what are you doing in England?
I am factotum to Nathaniel Whitlock. It was he who persuaded me to accompany him back to his homeland.
(FEIGNING UNDERSTANDING) Ah! Of course!
Who is Nathaniel Whitlock?
(PUZZLED) Your host. The great hunter and explorer? You are here for the Hunt?
Not exactly. Our... aeroplane ran into difficulties. We were forced to land on the other side of those trees.
(DOUBTFULLY) I see.
But how remiss of us. We haven’t introduced ourselves. I’m the Doctor and this is Nyssa. And you are...?
I am Silver Crow.
We’re delighted to meet you, Silver Crow! Aren’t we, Nyssa?
Yes.
(OFF/CROSSLY) I say! Are you aiming to keep us sitting here all night?
(CALLING) Apologies, Mr Tremayne.
It seems the natives are getting restless. Perhaps we ought to...?
(THOUGHTFULLY) Yes. (MORE DECISIVELY) Yes. Please, Doctor, Miss Nyssa, follow me.
MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 8
(FX: THEY TRUDGE ACROSS THE ROAD TO THE CARRIAGE, FEET CRUNCHING ON GRAVEL. SILVER CROW OPENS THE CARRIAGE DOOR WITH A CREAK)
Please make yourselves comfortable. There’s plenty of room inside.
After you, Nyssa.
Allow me.
Thank you.
(FX: CREAK OF THE CARRIAGE AS SHE STEPS UP AND IN, FOLLOWED BY THE DOCTOR)
MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 9
3. INT. CARRIAGE
(FX: CARRIAGE DOOR SHUT FIRMLY. OUTSIDE, SILVER CROW WALKS AROUND, MOUNTS DRIVER'S SEAT THROUGH: )
Well, isn’t this cosy?
And who might you be, sir?
(CURTLY) I might be any number of people.
This is the Doctor, and I’m Nyssa.
(FX: REINS OFF. CARRIAGE MOVES OFF, HOOVES CLOPPING, PICKING UP SPEED, THROUGH: )
How do you do? I’m Hector Tremayne, and this is my father-
(BUTTING IN) Edwin Tremayne. Doubtless you have heard of me.
I’m afraid not.
HUFFS IN DISGUST
My father is one of this country’s leading industrialists.
I see. Dark, satanic mills, that sort of thing?
And what do you do, Hector?
Well, I’d like [to] -
Hector will join the family business, of course, and eventually follow in my footsteps. If he proves himself worthy — which at present is by no means a certainty.
I see. And is that what you would like to do, Hector?
MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 10
Well, I —-
It is not a matter of like and dislike. (ANNOYED) And is not the place of a child to ask such an impertinent question.
I’m not a child.
And Nyssa is certainly not impertinent. Curious perhaps, which in my opinion is to be encouraged.
(COLDLY) Is that so, sir?
Absolutely. After all, if we don’t ask we don’t learn — do we, Mr Tremayne?
(HASTILY) Are you both here for the Hunt?
I take it that you are?
Naturally. My son is not keen, but I hold out the vain hope that the weekend will make a man of him.
(DISTASTEFULLY) You mean you’re here to kill animals for Sport? Like the lion that attacked us?
Is that a serious question?
Please indulge us. We’re not here by choice. As I explained to Mr, er, Crow, our aeroplane developed engine trouble and we were forced to make an unscheduled landing.
(ASTONISHED) You have an aeroplane?
Of a sort.
MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 11

In answer to your question, young lady, we will hunt whatever manner of beast our host has seen fit to ship in from the dark continent — gorillas, elephants, rhinoceroses. I hear he even has a pair of tigers from Bengal.
(HORRIFIED) And they’re all here purely so you can slaughter them?
It’s a noble enough pursuit. Man against nature.
It’s barbaric.
Nonsense. The animals themselves hunt, do they not?
Yes, for survival. And they don’t tip the odds in their favour by carrying weapons.
Oh, spare me your bleeding heart, girl. Be assured, it will meet with short shrift in the presence of our host.
(FX: CARRIAGE DRIVES ON. FADE TO:
MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 12
4. INT. DRAWING ROOM
FX: A FIRE CRACKLES IN THE GRATE
Would you care for an aperitif, Miss Bartholomew?
I would love one, my dear. And it’s ‘Ms’, not Miss — though I'd prefer it if you would simply call me Hannah. I can’t abide all this standing on ceremony.
I will be glad to. And you must call me Phoebe.
FX: SHE POURS SOME DRINKS. OVER THIS...
Phoebe. Such a pretty name. Will you be joining us in the saddle tomorrow?
I fear not.
You don’t share your father’s love of sport?
It is partly that. And partly that Father deems it unseemly for a lady to indulge in manly pursuits. (REALISING WHAT SHE’S SAYING, FLUSTERED) Oh! I meant no offence, Ms Bar... Hannah.
(HUSKY LAUGH) None taken, my dear. Perhaps I am not quite the ‘lady’ you think I should be, eh?
That’s not it at all.
So my choice of clothes doesn’t make you uncomfortable?
I think your breeches rather fetching. Besides, my father has always impressed upon me that I should judge my fellow man not by his outward appearance, but by his character.
(TEASINGLY) Your fellow man? What of your fellow woman?
That too, of course —
MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 13
I am teasing you, my dear Phoebe. Your outlook does you credit. Well — chin chin.
(LESS CONFIDENTLY; SHE’S UNFAMILIAR WITH THE LINGO) Chin chin.
FX: THEY CHINK GLASSES AND SIP THEIR DRINKS
Tell me, Phoebe, would you mind indulging my curiosity?
(WARILY) If I can.
The red rock beneath the glass dome on the sideboard. The one that glitters so strangely. May I ask what it is?
Oh, just one of the artefacts that Father has picked up on his travels. I’m sure that either he or Silver Crow will enlighten you as to its origin when they appear.
Yes, I’m sure they shall.
(FX: OFF/DISTANT — THE CLATTER OF A CARRIAGE DRAWING UP OUTSIDE)
Ah. Here is Silver Crow now, with the rest of this weekend’s
guests. Excuse me a moment, please... Hannah.
Certainly, my dear.
FX: PHOEBE EXITS. CROSS TO:
MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 14
5. INT. HALLWAY
(FX: A GRANDFATHER CLOCK TICKS SONOROUSLY. VOICES ECHO SLIGHTLY, DENOTING A SENSE OF SPACE)
(LEADING 4 x OTHERS IN) Please come in, gentlemen, Miss Nyssa. Your luggage, if you have any, will be taken directly to your rooms.
I say, what a magnificent house.
Indeed. It appears that your employer has travelled widely, Silver Crow. That’s a genuine Zulu shield on the wall there, if I’m not mistaken. And isn’t that an Aboriginal bullroarer?
Bullroarer?
A sort of musical instrument. You thread string through the hole in the top and whizz it around your head.
The travels of my friend have indeed taken him far beyond the reaches of most men, Doctor. And in the process he has acquired both great knowledge and wisdom.
Well, they do say that travel broadens the mind. I shall look forward to meeting Mr Whitlock.
He will be joining us presently, In the meantime, perhaps you would care for a drink in the drawing room?
Now you’re talking. Lead the way, sir.
FX: APPROACHING HURRIED FOOTSTEPS ON TILED FLOOR
(A LITTLE OUT OF BREATH) Welcome, gentlemen. I trust you had a pleasant journey? (SPOTS THE DOCTOR AND NYSSA, SURPRISED) Oh! I did not expect quite so many guests.
Forgive the intrusion, Miss...?
MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 15
I am Phoebe Whitlock. Daughter of Nathaniel Whitlock.
Very pleased to meet you, Miss Whitlock. I’m the Doctor, and this is Nyssa.
The Doctor has an aeroplane, Miss Whitlock! It crash-landed in your grounds.
Gosh.
After which one of your lions almost ate us.
How terrible! I trust that you both emerged from the ordeal unscathed?
We did, thank you.
(IMPATIENTLY) Didn’t someone mention drinks?
Oh, er... yes, of course.
Follow me.
FX: ALL WALK SWIFTLY OFF. CROSS TO:
MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 16
6. INT. DRAWING ROOM
FX: FADE UP CRACKLING FIRE. DRAWING ROOM DOORS OPEN
In here, please.
AS PHOEBE & 4 x GUESTS FILE IN:
Well, hello there! I say, this is quite a party!
Gentlemen, Miss Nyssa, may I present Ms Hannah Bartholomew? Ms Bartholomew, this is Mr Edwin and Mr Hector Tremayne. And this is the Doctor and Nyssa.
(GENERAL BABBLE OF GREETINGS, VOICES OVERLAPPING ONE ANOTHER.
EXCHANGE, AS OF SEVERAL CONVERSATIONS GOING ON AT ONCE)
(STIFFLY) Miss Bartholomew.
Mr Tremayne.
Very pleased to meet you, Ms Bartholomew.
Likewise, I’m sure.
Would you care for a drink, Miss Nyssa?
Oh, er... no, thank you.
How about you, Mr Tremayne?
I thought you’d never ask.
FX: THE CHINK OF CRYSTAL; DRINKS BEING POURED. OVER THIS...
(TEASINGLY) So you’re ‘the Doctor’? I take it you have a proper name?
MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 17
Probably. (WITH SUDDEN ENTHUSIASM) Oh, look! How very interesting!
FX: HE WALKS AWAY
(SHARPLY) Doctor! (TO HANNAH) I’m sorry about my friend. He tends to get distracted easily.
Not a bit of it, my dear. (RAISING HER VOICE) It is a rather magnificent rock, is it not?
(HER VOICE ALERTS THE OTHERS, WHO CLUSTER ROUND SIDEBOARD, FOCUSING ON THE OBJECT OF THE DOCTOR’S ATTENTION)
What the devil is it?
It looks like a.. a dinosaur egg made of crystal.
It’s not an egg, though it certainly appears to have a crystalline structure. (THOUGHTFULLY) I’ve never seen anything quite like it. Not on this planet anyway.
You mean it’s extra-terrestrial?
(SCOFFS) Extra-terrestrial!
It is moonflesh, Doctor.
Moon flesh?
I’m intrigued, Silver Crow. Tell me more.
When I was eighteen winters old, I danced the ghost dance, as is a tradition of my people.
Ah, yes. To reunite the living with the spirits of the dead and to bring peace, prosperity and unity to the tribe — that sort of thing?
MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 18
That sort of thing. (MUSIC: FADE IN NATIVE AMERICAN DANCE
MUSIC UNDER SILVER CROW’S ACCOUNT — SOMETHING EERIE,

MYSTERIOUS) During the dance, which lasted for many hours, I fell into a trance, whereby I felt my mind leaving my body and travelling up to join with the Wakan Tanka, the Great Spirit, who is in and of all things. (MUSIC: QUICK FADE OUT) When I eventually woke from my trance I opened my fist... and there in my hand was the moonflesh, which Wakan Tanka had given to me and allowed me to bring back from the stars.
Fascinating.
(AWED) Is it really from the moon, do you think?
Don’t be ridiculous, boy. In all likelihood the fellow just grabbed it out of the dirt while he was thrashing about in this trance of his.
You’re suggesting it was simply lying about on the ground, Mr Tremayne? If that’s the case, don’t you think someone might have spotted it earlier?
Could it be a meteorite, Doctor, that came down during the ritual?
Possibly. But if Silver Crow believes Wakan Tanka presented the moonflesh to him as a gift, then who are we to doubt him?
Hear hear.
(DISGUSTEDLY) You’re all utterly mad.
There are more things in Heaven and Earth, Mr Tremayne...
(FX: DISTANT BUT APPROACHING — THE BARKING OF DOGS, THE
SCRABBLE OF CLAWS)
Speaking of which, what’s that? Are we about to be visited by the hounds of Hell?
MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 19
(TEASINGLY) Don’t be silly, Mr Tremayne.
(FX: TWO OVER-EXCITED HUNTING HOUNDS BURST INTO THE ROOM, BARKING. AGAIN RESPONSES ARE QUICK-FIRE/OVERLAPPING)
(CHARGED AT AND NUZZLED) Good Lord!
(LAUGHING) Get down, Brutus! He’s only being friendly, Mr —
Hector. (GAMELY) I’m sure he is, Miss Whitlock.
(GROOMING OTHER DOG) Oh, aren’t you beautiful! What’s your name?
Portia, of course.
She seems to like you, Doctor.
(BEING SLOBBERED OVER) She does, doesn’t she? You know, I’ve always got on terribly well with dogs.
Didn’t you say exactly the same thing about cats?
(FX: DOGS BARKING EXCITEDLY. GLASS SMASHED BY OVERENTHUSIASTIC TAIL)
For goodness’ sake, can’t you get these mutts out of here? That was my drink.
Sorry, Mr Tremayne. Silver Crow, would you mind taking Brutus and Portia to the kitchen?
I shall try, Miss Phoebe. —
(APPROACHING HEAVILY FROM OFF) Brutus! Portia! Heel!
FX: DOGS FALL SUDDENLY SILENT, TROT OFF
MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 20
You’ve got ’em well trained, sir.
Of course, sir! (TO ROOM) So — here you all are, at last.
Our host, I presume-?
Welcome to Whitlock Manor! I trust that my daughter has been attending to your- (BREAKS OFF) Hang about! Who the devil are
you-?
(UNDER BREATH) Here we go again.
Two more mouths to feed. Ain’t my hospitality famous?
MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 21
7. INT. DINING ROOM
(FX: FADE UP. SEVEN AT DINNER, CROW SERVING. CLINK AND SCRAPE OF CUTLERY ON CHINA PLATES )
So the lioness almost gobbled you up, did she, Doctor?
Yes, it was rather a shock.
Not as much as a shock as Silver Crow’s arrow gave her, I’11l be bound. (BEAT — WAITS FOR LAUGH FROM COMPANY — THEN FILLS IT IH HIMSELF) Eh? Eh? Haw!
EDWIN/HECTOR/HANNAH:
LAUGH POLITELY
It wasn’t a laughing matter, Mr Whitlock. We were almost killed — and the poor animal died.

Law of the jungle, dear girl. When a chap has been in the scrapes that I have, he learns to toughen up, to realise that in order to forge ahead in this world there are times when he needs to be ruthless — and in some cases to kill or be killed.
Yes, but if you had a tranquilliser [gun] —
(SOTTO) Not in nineteen-eleven. (TO NATHANIEL) Please, do continue, sir.

I once remember tramping over Greenland with a hungry polar bear on my tail. But did I dilly-dally in the hope that it would simply lose interest and wander off? No, I turned and faced the brute. Put a bullet through its brain. But that wasn’t an end to it. Not by a long chalk. (SUDDENLY ROUNDING ON HECTOR) Now then, Master Tremayne. Little test for you. You’re cold, you’re tired, you’re hungry. You have a dead polar bear lying at your feet. What do you do?
Well, I, er.. I expect you use it as a resource.
MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 22

Precisely! You keep yourself warm with its fur, you fill your belly with its flesh — not the liver, mind; that’s poison — you use its claws as toothpicks if needs be! Second rule of the hunter: waste nothing. As a businessman I expect that’s a sentiment you concur with all too readily, Mr Tremayne?
Oh yes. Quite right, Mr Whitlock. (ASIDE, TO SILVER CROW) More wine, Crow.
Sir.
FX: POURS WINE
Second rule of the hunter, you said. So what’s the first?
Keep you wits about you at all times — and keep your gun loaded. (LAUGHS)
Perhaps if you hadn’t invaded the polar bear’s habitat in the first place, Mr Whitlock, the circumstances leading to its death would not have arisen.
True, my dear. But is it not in man’s nature to seek to master all of his environment, even its furthest reaches? What do you say, Doctor?
I’1l remain firmly on the fence. I sympathise with Nyssa’s viewpoint, and I would never kill for sport —
What?
. but were I one of Silver Crow’s people, for instance, I wouldn’t have the luxury of a higher perspective. Tell me, Mr Whitlock, how long have you and Silver Crow known each other?
Our acquaintance began six years ago, when I spent the year of nineteen hundred and five among his tribe. Taught me how to hunt buffalo with a bow and arrow — didn’t you, Crow?
MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 23
Mr Nathaniel mastered in a summer skills some men take a lifetime to learn.

But just as I was eager to see how the red man lives, Crow here hankered to see the world beyond the plains. So he came back home with me — and has been my constant companion in my travels, ever since.
Have never regretted leaving your people, Mr Crow?
I carry them in my heart at all times. Perhaps one day I will go back. But my life is here now.
Silver Crow has become very much part of the family.
And what of your mother, Miss Whitlock?
I am afraid she died when I was a little girl.

(SOMBRE) Ah, my sweet Audrey. She succumbed to fever in December of nineteen hundred and one. This coming winter will mark the tenth anniversary of her passing. (ROUSES HIMSELF) But enough maudlin talk. I have several excellent bottles of whiskey and a vintage port direct from the Douro Valley in my cellar. What say we gentlemen retire to the drawing room for a night-cap? It is not often that I have the luxury of guests to converse with.
(TEASINGLY) To regale with your stories of derring-do, you
mean, Father?
(LAUGHS) Ah, you know me so well, child.
That sounds like an excellent idea, Mr Whitlock.
FX: ALL RISE OUT OF CHAIRS THROUGH:
Crow — you won’t partake of the firewater, of course?
MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 24
Please excuse me if I don’t join you, gentlemen. If that’s all, I will wish you good night.
CHORUS OF ‘GOOD NIGHTS’ AS HE LEAVES
Thank you for your hospitality, Mr Whitlock, but... shouldn’t we be leaving too, Doctor?
Nonsense, my dear! It’s far too dangerous to venture out after dark. I insist that you stay here as my guests tonight.
Thank you, Mr Whitlock. We’d be delighted to accept your invitation. Wouldn’t we, Nyssa?
(RELUCTANTLY) Yes.
Excellent. Well, gentlemen, shall we leave the ladies to it?

Ladies? I do hope you’re not including me in that category, Mr Whitlock? Like Mr Tremayne and his son, I am here to hunt this weekend. And, like them, I have paid handsomely for the benefit of your unparalleled experience — a modicum of which, no doubt, you are imminently about to impart? Besides... (TEASING HUMOUR) I do enjoy a glass of port after dinner. Particularly one from the Douro Valley.
MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 25
8. INT. STAIRCASE/LANDING
(FX: FADE UP CREAK OF PHOEBE’S AND NYSSA’S ASCENDING FOOTSTEPS ON WOODEN STAIRS)
Are you certain you would not like a cup of cocoa before you retire, Miss Nyssa? It really is no trouble.
No, thank you, Phoebe. It’s kind of you, but I’m very tired.
Silver Crow has made up a bed for you on the fourth floor. The room is high enough that you won’t be disturbed by the chatter of the men downstairs.
Thank you. Don’t most houses this size have servants?

We used to have servants (HESITANTLY) .. but I am afraid that Father’s fortunes are not as they were. His father — my grandfather — acquired his wealth by importing and selling tea from East India, but I’m afraid that Father does not have the same head for business. He spends half of his time off on his adventures, and the other half procuring the finances to enable him to do so — hence weekends such as this one. (REALISING SHE’S SAID TOO MUCH) But I am speaking out of turn.
I’m sorry, Phoebe. It must be hard for you.
Oh, the three of us muddle along very well, and I do love Father very dearly. Though I confess I do get a little lonely whenever he and Silver Crow are off on one of their expeditions.
I’m not surprised, rattling about in this big house all by yourself. (STARTLED) Oh!
(FX: THEIR FOOTSTEPS FALTER AT THE TOP OF THE STAIRS, THEN
(LAUGHS) Sorry, Nyssa, I should have warned you. They are a rather arresting sight, all lined up in a row above the stairwell.
MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 26
Are they statues?
Native American gods, carved in wood. This one is Tunka, the Stone God, the most ancient of the Sioux deities. And that is Ptesan Wi, the White Buffalo Woman.
They look more like warriors than gods.
Silver Crow’s tribe believe that spirits live in mountains, rivers, rocks — pebbles, even.
Do you think the same?
(SLIGHTLY AGHAST) Of course not, I’m no heathen.
(SNIFFING) What’s that smell? Is something burning?
That’ll be Silver Crow, his room is just along the corridor. He uses herbs help him meditate. It’s his way of keeping in contact with his ancestors.
The scent is rather pungent.
Yes, best not to linger. Your room is on the right at the top, Nyssa. Shall I show you?
There’s no need. I’m sure I shall manage. Goodnight.
FX: WALKS OFF, UPSTAIRS
Goodnight, Nyssa. Sleep well.
FX: TURNS AND WALKS BACK DOWN. FADE TO:
MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 27
9. INT. NYSSA’S ROOM
(FX: FAINTLY, FROM OFF/OUTSIDE, WE HEAR THE CRY OF AN OWL,
BY THE SOFT RUSTLE OF BEDCLOTHES AS NYSSA TURNS OVER IN HER SLEEP. SHE MURMURS WORDLESSLY, THEN HER BREATHING
OUT, BECOMING SLOW AND DEEP. SUDDENLY...)
OFF/DISTANT) (SCREAMS
FX: BRIEF COMMOTION OF BEDCLOTHES AS NYSSA ABRUPTLY SITS UP
(CONFUSED) Doctor? (BECOMING MORE AWARE/RAISES VOICE) Phoebe?
(FX: SHE SCRAMBLES OUT OF BED AND HER BARE FEET PAD RAPIDLY
MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 28
10. INT. STAIRCASE/LANDING/CORRIDOR [CONTINUOUS]
FX: DOOR OPENS
(CALLING) Phoebe?
(OFF, FROM THE LANDING BELOW) Nyssa? Is that you up there?
(RUSHING DOWN STAIRCASE) Doctor! I heard a scream.
So did I. It came from the floor below. Come on!
(FX: THEY THUMP DOWN THE STAIRS. AS THEY REACH THE LANDING BELOW A DOOR OPENS)
Silver Crow!
I heard a cry from Ms Bartholomew’s room.
Which one is that?
At the end of the corridor.
Come on, quickly.

And, like them, I have paid handsomely for the benefit of your unparalleled experience — a modicum of which, no doubt, you are imminently about to impart? Besides... (TEASING HUMOUR) I do enjoy a glass of port after dinner. Particularly one from the Douro Valley.
DOCTOR WHO: MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 25
DOCTOR WHO: (FX: FADE UP CREAK OF PHOEBE’S AND NYSSA’S ASCENDING FOOTSTEPS ON WOODEN STAIRS)
PHOEBE: Are you certain you would not like a cup of cocoa before you retire, Miss Nyssa? It really is no trouble.
NYSSA: No, thank you, Phoebe. It’s kind of you, but I’m very tired.
PHOEBE: Silver Crow has made up a bed for you on the fourth floor. The room is high enough that you won’t be disturbed by the chatter of the men downstairs.
NYSSA: Thank you. Don’t most houses this size have servants?
PHOEBE: We used to have servants (HESITANTLY) .. but I am afraid that Father’s fortunes are not as they were. His father — my grandfather — acquired his wealth by importing and selling tea from East India, but I’m afraid that Father does not have the same head for business. He spends half of his time off on his adventures, and the other half procuring the finances to enable him to do so — hence weekends such as this one. (REALISING SHE’S SAID TOO MUCH) But I am speaking out of turn.
NYSSA: I’m sorry, Phoebe. It must be hard for you.
PHOEBE: Oh, the three of us muddle along very well, and I do love Father very dearly. Though I confess I do get a little lonely whenever he and Silver Crow are off on one of their expeditions.
NYSSA: I’m not surprised, rattling about in this big house all by yourself. (STARTLED) Oh!
NYSSA: (FX: THEIR FOOTSTEPS FALTER AT THE TOP OF THE STAIRS, THEN
HALT: )
PHOEBE: (LAUGHS) Sorry, Nyssa, I should have warned you. They are a rather arresting sight, all lined up in a row above the stairwell.
DOCTOR WHO: MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 26
NYSSA: Are they statues?
PHOEBE: Native American gods, carved in wood. This one is Tunka, the Stone God, the most ancient of the Sioux deities. And that is Ptesan Wi, the White Buffalo Woman.
NYSSA: They look more like warriors than gods.
PHOEBE: Silver Crow’s tribe believe that spirits live in mountains, rivers, rocks — pebbles, even.
NYSSA: Do you think the same?
PHOEBE: (SLIGHTLY AGHAST) Of course not, I’m no heathen.
NYSSA: (SNIFFING) What’s that smell? Is something burning?
PHOEBE: That’ll be Silver Crow, his room is just along the corridor. He uses herbs help him meditate. It’s his way of keeping in contact with his ancestors.
NYSSA: The scent is rather pungent.
PHOEBE: Yes, best not to linger. Your room is on the right at the top, Nyssa. Shall I show you?
NYSSA: There’s no need. I’m sure I shall manage. Goodnight.
PHOEBE: Goodnight, Nyssa. Sleep well.
DOCTOR WHO: MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 27
DOCTOR WHO: (FX: FAINTLY, FROM OFF/OUTSIDE, WE HEAR THE CRY OF AN OWL,
FOLLOWED: BY THE SOFT RUSTLE OF BEDCLOTHES AS NYSSA TURNS OVER IN HER SLEEP. SHE MURMURS WORDLESSLY, THEN HER BREATHING
LEVELS: OUT, BECOMING SLOW AND DEEP. SUDDENLY...)
NYSSA: (CONFUSED) Doctor? (BECOMING MORE AWARE/RAISES VOICE) Phoebe?
NYSSA: (FX: SHE SCRAMBLES OUT OF BED AND HER BARE FEET PAD RAPIDLY
DOCTOR WHO: MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 28
NYSSA: (CALLING) Phoebe?
DOCTOR: (OFF, FROM THE LANDING BELOW) Nyssa? Is that you up there?
NYSSA: (RUSHING DOWN STAIRCASE) Doctor! I heard a scream.
DOCTOR: So did I. It came from the floor below. Come on!
DOCTOR: (FX: THEY THUMP DOWN THE STAIRS. AS THEY REACH THE LANDING BELOW A DOOR OPENS)
DOCTOR: Silver Crow!
SILVER CROW: I heard a cry from Ms Bartholomew’s room.
DOCTOR: Which one is that?
SILVER CROW: At the end of the corridor.
NYSSA: Come on, quickly.
DOCTOR: It’s locked.
DOCTOR: Ms Bartholomew? Ms Bartholomew, can you hear me?
HANNAH: (VOICE TIGHT, TERRIFIED, MUFFLED BY THE DOOR) Yes.
DOCTOR: Are you all right?
DOCTOR WHO: MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 29
DOCTOR: Speak to me, Hannah. Can you open this door?
HANNAH: (VOICE TIGHT, TERRIFIED, MUFFLED BY THE DOOR) I daren’t move.
SILVER CROW: Stand back, Doctor. (EFFORT, AS...)
SILVER CROW: (FX: SILVER CROW SLAMS A SHOULDER AGAINST THE DOOR. WITH A SPLINTERING OF WOOD IT FLIES OPEN. CUT TO: )
DOCTOR WHO: MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL)
DOCTOR WHO: (FX: AS THEY ENTER, FADE UP FIZZING, CRACKLING SOUND — NOT AS
HARSH: AS ELECTRICITY, SOFTER, MORE ORGANIC — BUT STILL ANGRY)
DOCTOR: Hannah? What is it?
HANNAH: (TERRIFIED, POINTING) It’s there.
NYSSA: Doctor, look! By the fireplace!
DOCTOR: I see it. Fascinating.
NYSSA: What is it? Why is it glowing red like that?
DOCTOR: It’s some kind of energy. Energy in corporeal form.
SILVER CROW: (CRIES OUT IN FEAR) It is Tunka!
DOCTOR: (STEPPING FORWARD) Tunka?
DOCTOR: (FX: THE FIZZING, CRACKLING SOUND ABRUPTLY BECOMES FIERCER,
DOCTOR: LOUDER, ANGRIER)
HANNAH: Get back! It’s going to attack!
NYSSA: Doctor!!!
NYSSA: END OF PART ONE
DOCTOR WHO: MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 31

elements.text: PART TWO
REPRISE:
Doctor, look! By the fireplace!
I see it. Fascinating.
What is it? Why is it glowing red like that?
It’s some kind of energy. Energy in corporeal form.
(CRIES OUT IN FEAR) It is Tunka!
(STEPPING FORWARD) Tunka?
(FX: THE FIZZING, CRACKLING SOUND ABRUPTLY BECOMES FIERCER, LOUDER, ANGRIER)
Get back! It’s going to attack!
Doctor!!!
12. INT. HANNAH’S ROOM [CONTINUED]
FX: THE FIZZING, CRACKLING SOUND REACHES A CRESCENDO
(BARGING IN FROM OUTSIDE) Out of the way! Let me get at the blighter!
Mr Whitlock, [no —]
(FX: DOUBLE FIREARMS BLAST AS HE TAKES A COUPLE OF SHOTS AT THE ENERGY CREATURE WITH HIS HUNTING RIFLE, AND A CRACK AS THE
PASS THROUGH IT AND EMBED THEMSELVES IN THE WALL)
(FX: THE FIZZING, CRACKLING SOUND CHANGES TIMBRE, VEERING
It’s retreating!
MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 32
Up the chimney, yes.
(FX: FADE DOWN FIZZING, CRACKLING SOUND, WHICH BECOMES HOLLOW,
AS THE CREATURE FLIES UP THE CHIMNEY. FADE TO SILENCE)
Is everyone all right? Ms Bartholomew?
(SHAKILY) Yes... I think so.
What was that damned apparition?
(AWE-STRUCK) It was Tunka, the most ancient of our gods.
A life-form in the shape of Tunka, perhaps.
You mean that was something alive?
Not life in the sense that you would understand it, Mr Whitlock, [but —]
Yes it was. Very much so.
Good lord.
So where’s it gone now?
I wish I knew.
MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 33
13. INT. PHOEBE’S BEDROOM
FX: FRANTIC BANGING ON BEDROOM DOOR
(OUTSIDE DOOR, VOICE MUFFLED) Miss Phoebe! Miss Phoebe!
(WAKING UP, CONFUSED) What? (COMING TO) Mr Tremayne? Is that you?
(OUTSIDE DOOR) Hector, yes. Is all well with you, Miss Phoebe?
One moment, please. —
(FX: THROWS BACK COVERS AND GETS UP, BEDSPRINGS CREAKING. THE RUSTLE OF CLOTHING AS SHE PUTS ON A ROBE AND PADS TO THE DOOR.

It’s just that I thought I heard something. A scream. A gunshot. (RUNNING OUT OF STEAM; AFRAID THAT HE’S MAKING A FOOL OF HIMSELF) And, well, I felt compelled, rather, to come and see that you were — [all right.]
FX: DOOR OPENS
As you can see, I am perfectly fine.
(GULP) I’1ll say.
(SCANDALISED) Mr Tremayne!
Oh! I didn’t mean — well, what I meant to say was — Oh dear.
(AMUSED) It was very gallant of you to enquire after my welfare, Mr Tremayne.
Please... call me Hector. ‘Mr Tremayne’ makes me sound like my father. (LAUGHS UNCERTAINLY) So you didn’t hear anything?
I’m afraid not. But then I do sleep very [soundly. ]
MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 34 (FX: OVER THIS, OFF/OUTSIDE THE WINDOW, RISING FIZZING/CRACKLING OF THE ENERGY-CREATURE )
Hush! (BEAT) Can you hear that?
Yes I can. (FX: SHE CROSSES THE ROOM) It’s outside the window!
(FOLLOWING, NERVOUS) Please, Miss Phoebe, allow me to —
(AT WINDOW) I can pull a curtain for myself, Mr Tremayne. —
FX: PHOEBE DRAWS BACK A CURTAIN WITH A SINGLE SHARP TUG
GASPS IN SHOCK
(FX: THE FIZZING/CRACKLING IS LOUD, SEPARATED FROM THEM BY NO
THAN A PANE OF GLASS)
(SHOCKED) My goodness, what is that?
It’s like.. (CURIOUS) I don’t know, a ball of red lightning.
(HORRIFIED) I feel as though... as though it’s looking at us. Oh, it’s horrible!
FX: FIZZING/CRACKLING MOVES OFF, OVER THEM
It’s flying away. Over the roof!
FX: THE FIZZING/CRACKLING HAS GONE
It’s gone, I think. (EXHALES) Great heavens, that was frightful. Look at me, I’m shaking like a leaf.
(SARCASTIC) Oh, Hector. My hero!
MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 35
14. INT. HANNAH’S ROOM
Doctor — if that thing really is alive, as you claim, then I doubt it will last long in my jungle. Big cats’1l make mincemeat of it.
I wouldn’t be so sure, Mr Whitlock.
But where did it come from?
Exactly what I was wondering, Nyssa. Perhaps Ms Bartholomew can enlighten us?
(RECOVERING) I’m sure I have no idea what you mean, Doctor.
Really? (FX: TWO STEPS TO WINDOW, PICKS UP KNIFE) So this pocket knife, and these crystal scrapings on your counterpane are a complete mystery to you, too?
(WRYLY) Oh. It seems I am undone.
I’m afraid it does.
What the devil? Who are you, girl?

I’m sorry to have deceived you, Mr Whitlock — or rather, I’m sorry that my true motives for attending this weekend’s activities have been uncovered in such an ignominious manner. Because despite what you may think, I am an ardent admirer of yours. And I truly didn’t mean any harm.
Stop beating around the bush. (HEFTING SHOTGUN) Or you too may find that the only way to evade a bullet is to fly up the chimney like fairy dust.
(SIGHS) I came here for the moonflesh. Or rather, for a sample of it. A portion so inconsequential that you would not even have noticed its absence.
MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 36
You knew of the moonflesh before you arrived here tonight?
Indeed I did. It came to our attention when Mr Whitlock gave a lecture at the Royal Society several months ago, and enlivened his talk with artefacts he had procured on his travels.
The moonflesh included, I remember!
‘Our attention.’ You said, ‘our attention.’
Indeed you did. Who are you working for, Ms Bartholomew?
I represent a group called the Order of the Crescent Moon.
(DERISIVE SNORT) That ill-informed rabble-?!
A religious society?
Hardly, my dear. At least, not in the conventional sense. They believe that mankind is in the thrall of invisible beings who stroll through time and space — or some such idiocy.
I see.

That is a gross misrepresentation of our core doctrine. We believe that all of Time is a never-ending circle, like the phases of the moon — and that life as we know it is merely our moment in Time’s limelight, until we move beyond our mortal form.
What happens then?
Why, we become spirits, moving through the shadows to guide those mortals in the light, just as we in turn hope to be guided when the circle turns and our time comes to live again.
Whichever way you look at it, it’s utter rot.
MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 37

You are entitled to your opinion, Mr Whitlock, just as I am entitled to disagree. I am unshakeable in my beliefs, and no amount of ridicule or contempt will sway me from my course. Nevertheless, I have no wish to convert you to my way of thinking.
Believe me, young lady, you would not succeed in doing so even if you did.
This is all terribly interesting, but I rather think we’re losing sight of the matter in hand.
The Doctor is right. We should be more concerned by the whereabouts of Tunka.
Once we establish its nature then perhaps we can work out how to deal with it. If you could tell us exactly what happened, Ms Bartholomew?
I remained awake until the house was silent, whereupon I crept downstairs. I removed the moonflesh from the drawing room and brought it up here, intending to replace it in minutes —
So you say.
Please, continue.
I took the knife you see there from my overnight bag, and used it to scrape a number of small crystals from the surface of the moonflesh.
In Heaven’s name, why?
We believe that the moonflesh may be sacred — a gift from the Spirits — and that it may bestow us with the ability to communicate with the other side.
But the result was rather more spectacular than you were anticipating?
MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 38
Yes. No sooner had I set my knife to the task than the moonflesh... changed.
How, exactly?

It writhed in my hands, and became hot. I dropped it, and it split apart, into a stream of swirling crystals. It made a sound — an angry crackling, as you heard. Then it rose from the bed and crossed to the far side of the room, rippling through the air like a glowing red serpent. Once there, it gathered itself in the corner and began to take shape —
The shape of Tunka.
That was when I screamed.
Interesting. The creature must have been in some suspended state, and when it felt threatened it reverted to its original form. How long has the moonflesh been in your possession, Silver Crow?
Over twenty summers, Doctor.
To some life-forms, twenty years is no more than the blink of an eye.
What is this creature, if not Tunka himself? A trickster, perhaps?
Perhaps these crystals will give us a clue to its origins — once I’ve analysed them, at least.
We’re going back to the TARDIS?
No. Our priority must be to find this creature and communicate With 2t.
And how do you propose we do that, Doctor?
MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 39
We must go looking for it, Mr Whitlock. At first light we must organise a search-party.
(GLEEFULLY) A hunt?! Now you’re talking!
MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 40
15. EXT. GROUNDS OF WHITLOCK MANOR — OPEN LAND
(FX: FADE UP 6 x HORSES, TROTTING GENTLY ACROSS SOFT/GRASSY GROUND. SOFT JANGLE OF BRIDLES, ETC)
NB: ALL SIX MEMBERS OF THE SEARCH-PARTY ARE ON HORSEBACK
(TROTTING) Damn foolish of you to refuse the offer of a rifle, Doctor.
(TROTTING) In my experience it’s hard to make friends with someone if you’re pointing a gun at them, Mr Whitlock.
(FX: OFF/DISTANT, THE TRUMPETING OF AN ELEPHANT. A COUPLE OF
WHINNY ANXIOUSLY. ALL COME TO STOP)
(SCATHINGLY) But in the meantime, you’re happy to rely on the rest of us to protect you from the wildlife?
If we keep our heads and act as agreed, there won’t be any need for bloodshed at all.
The Doctor’s right, Mr Tremayne. We discussed this at great length over breakfast — or weren’t you listening?
No animal is likely to attack — or even approach — a party such as ours, so long as we remain together.
And if an animal does venture too close, Silver Crow will fire a warning arrow to frighten it off.

You’re in no position to lecture me, girl. Frankly, it baffles me as to why you’re even here. The reason that this creature is at large is entirely due to your underhandedness. If it was down to me, not only would you have remained back at the house with Miss Whitlock and the Doctor’s companion, but you’d have been clapped in irons for good measure.
(TEASINGLY) Oh, Mr Tremayne, I didn’t know you cared.
Ms Bartholomew is here because she wishes to make amends, Father. Personally I think it’s an admirable gesture.
MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 41
Thank you, Hector.
(SNEERING) And what would you know about anything, boy?
(RAISING HIS VOICE) Let’s try to stay focused, shall we? Bickering will only prove a distraction — possibly a fatal one.

The Doctor speaks the truth. A good hunter remains aware of his senses at all times. He must watch not only with his eyes, but with his skin, his hair, his belly and his mind. He must feel his surroundings, become a part of it.

Well said, Silver Crow. Now stay alert as we head into the trees, everyone. Predators may not have our intelligence, but they’re cunning nevertheless, and they know exactly where the best hiding places are. A moment’s laxity and you could find yourself being ripped apart before you can blink.
You sound as though you’re enjoying this, Mr Whitlock.
Nothing makes a man feels more alive than the possibility of imminent death, Ms Bartholomew. (RAISING HIS VOICE) Is everybody ready?
Aye!
Er, yes.
I suppose so.
Then on we go.
(FX: 6 x HORSES MOVE OFF. CRACKLE AND CRUNCH OF DRY LEAVES AS THEY PUSH ON INTO THE WOODS)
MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL)
16. INT. DRAWING ROOM
FX: THE CRACKLE AND POP OF THE FIRE
Oh, I hate all this waiting around.
You are very restless, Nyssa.
I should have gone with the others. I listened to the Doctor.
He was only trying to protect you.
I don’t need protecting. (PAUSE) Well, he.
should never have
sometimes. But so does
Well, I for one am glad you did not go. Your company makes the
waiting easier. Is that selfish of me?
No, not at all.
(CAGILY) Who is he — this Doctor of yours? Your guardian?
In a way. I started travelling with him after my parents died. We're... friends. Companions. And nothing more, before you ask.
(SIGHS) I wish I had a companion. Someone I could talk to.
Don’t you have any friends?
Not really. If Mother were here we would doubtless go out visiting together, take tea, do all the things that ladies do.
But Father discourages visitors.
It sounds as though he keeps you a prisoner.
MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 43
Oh no. He is very kind. I want for nothing within these walls. But he does not understand how lonely I am, how much I crave the companionship of someone of my own age.
Like Hector you mean?
(COYLY) Well, I... he seems a very pleasant young man.
You should talk to him. Properly, I mean. Ask him to call on you when all this is over.
(SHOCKED) I couldn’t do that!
Whyever not?
BEAT
(CHANGING SUBJECT) Oh, I do hope they’1ll be safe out there.
They will be if the Doctor’s got anything to do with it.
MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 44
17. EXT. GROUNDS OF WHITLOCK MANOR — WOODLAND
FX: 6 X HORSES MOVING THROUGH DRY LEAVES
The birds have stopped singing.
They are fearful.
And how do you presume to know that?
Silver Crow is at one with nature, Mr Tremayne. You should take heed of what he says.
(PULLING UP HORSE) Would everyone mind if we stopped for a moment?
FX: OTHER 5 x HORSES STOP. ODD SNORT
For what reason, Doctor?
We’re being watched.
(SNORTS WITH DERISION) I suppose you’re ‘at one’ with nature too?
Not exactly.
What then? Do you possess second sight, Doctor?
Let’s just say that my senses are a little more attuned than most people’s.
Silver Crow? What do you think?
I believe the Doctor is right.
Oh, my.
MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 45
(HUSHED BUT NOT SOTTO) So — what do we do, Doctor?
Well, we extend the hand of friendship and see what happens. (CALLING SOFTLY) Hello. I know you’re there. Don’t be afraid. We only want to help you.
(MUTTERS DERISIVELY) You think this creature will understand English?
It will understand me.
Will it now? And what makes you so [special] -
(FX: CUT SHORT BY A CRASH OF BRANCHES FROM OVERHEAD AS A
DROPS FROM THE TREES, SHRIEKING. HORSES WHINNY AND REAR IN PANIC...)
Gorilla! Look out, Tremayne!
(FX: A CRUNCHING THUD AS THE GORILLA SWIPES EDWIN FROM HIS HORSE WITH A SINGLE BLOW)
CRIES OUT IN PAIN
(SHOUTS) Father!
(SHOUTS) Mr Tremayne is down! Help him someone!
(TO THE HORSE) Ya! Ya!
(FX: HE SNAPS THE REINS, THE HORSE WHINNIES IN TERROR, ITS
THUDDING RAPIDLY ON THE GROUND AS HECTOR MANOUEVRES IT BETWEEN THE GORILLA AND HIS STRICKEN FATHER. THE GORILLA ROARS AGAIN. OVER THIS...)
Get back, boy! It’1ll kill you!
(OFF) I must save my father!
MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 46
(SCREAMS) Silver Crow! Shoot it! Kill it-!
No, please-!
I cannot get a clear shot —
Out of the way, Crow —
(FX: THE GORILLA LETS LOOSE A FINAL, EAR-SPLITTING ROAR. NEXT
THERE IS THE TWIN BLAST OF A HUNTING RIFLE AND THE
TOPPLES WITH AN ALMIGHTY THUD. ALL FALLS QUIET)
I do wish you hadn’t done that, Mr Whitlock.
(DISMOUNTING) You’re right. One hundred and fifty pounds, that creature cost.
FX: FOLLOW NATHANIEL AS HE WALKS OVER TO HECTOR
I’m sorry, Mr Whitlock, sir —
Dismount, boy. I said, dismount!
FX: AS HECTOR DISMOUNTS:
(OFF) Is Mr Tremayne-?
GROANS IN PAIN
He’s hurt, but not too badly, I think.
Easy for you to say. Gah, my leg! I think it’s broken!
(OFF) We should take Mr Tremayne back to the house.
FX: INJURED GORILLA WHINES
Oh Lord. The gorilla’s not dead.
MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 47
That was an incredibly foolish thing to do, boy, riding your horse between an animal and its prey like that.
Its ‘prey’, as you call it, was my father. What else could I do?
(GRUNTS) Yes, well. (FX: PASSING SHOTGUN) Here. Take my gun.
Whatever for?
I only wounded the beast.
You mean...?
(SADISTIC) Someone’s got to put it out of its misery.
But I can’t-! Really-!
(TROTTING OVER) Please, don’t torment the boy!
(TO HECTOR) ‘Boy’, exactly. Now, Hector — let’s see the man.
(FX: TWO MORE RIFLE BLASTS AS HECTOR FIRES INTO THE GORILLA’S
BODY. BEAT. HORSES SNORT)
Damned unusual for a gorilla to attack like that, mind.
No, they’re not usually violent, unless provoked. (A THOUGHT) Or unless — (STOPS SHORT)
Unless what?
Stand back from the body, Hector. You too, Whitlock.
Why? It’s quite [dead.] (SUDDEN SURPRISE) Good Lord!
MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 48
Yes, I see it too.
Its fur — it’s rippling, like there’s something alive beneath the [skin. ]
(FX: FIZZING/CRACKLING OF THE ENERGY-CREATURE ERUPTING FROM
GORILLA)
GENERAL ALARM
The Tunka!
The energy-form. Get back, everyone!
Good grief! That creature must have been inside the gorilla! Inside its body.
Doing what?
Feeding on it? Like some kind of parasite?
More likely manipulating its movements.
You mean that thing made the gorilla attack my father?
I’m afraid so.
Which means it’s hostile. (FX: SNATCHING THE GUN BACK OFF HECTOR) Give me the gun back, lad —
(SHOUTS) Nathaniel, no!
(FX: TWO RIFLE BLASTS AS NATHANIEL FIRES AT THE ALIEN. THE
PASS THROUGH, HITTING TREES WITH A SPLINTERING OF WOOD. THE CRACKLING, FIZZING GROWS MOMENTARILY LOUDER, ANGRIER, THEN FADES AS THE ALIEN ASCENDS INTO THE TREES)
It’s retreating!
MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 49
(SHOUTS) Come back! We want to help you!
FX: CRACKLING, FIZZING OF THE ALIEN FADES TO SILENCE
It’s gone.
(ANGRILY) Couldn’t you have kept that trigger finger of yours still even for a second?
(ALSO ANGRY) The beast attacked Mr Tremayne!
It could have killed him!

(CALMING DOWN) I know... I know, I’m sorry. You were very brave, Hector. And you were only doing what you thought was right, Nathaniel. But we’ve already established that bullets have no effect on it. You might as well try killing smoke. By shooting at it, all we’re achieving is cementing the notion that we’re hostile.
But is the creature’s attack on Mr Tremayne not proof that it means us harm, Doctor?
Not necessarily. It could be frightened or confused, lashing out because it thinks that it’s under threat.
Damn it all, Whitlock — I’1l go to law if you don’t get me attention!
We must get my father back to the house.
Yes. You do that. But I need to get to my... erm, aeroplane. I’ve got some scientific equipment there that will enable me to analyse these crystal samples.
Don’t be a fool, man. You can’t go alone.
(TROTTING FORWARD) Then I shall accompany the Doctor, to act as his protector.
MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 50
There’s really no need.
I insist upon it.
(CHUCKLES) I’d advise you to comply, Doctor. When Silver Crow gets an idea into his head, there’s no shifting him. He’s the most stubborn fellow I’ve ever met.
Oh, I wouldn’t be so sure about that, Mr Whitlock. (TAKING REINS) Come on, Silver Crow.
FX: DOCTOR AND SILVER CROW TROT OFF. FADE
MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 51
18. INT. DRAWING ROOM
FX: FADE UP CRACKLE AND POP OF THE FIRE. NYSSA PACING
Nyssa, dear — why don’t you sit by the fire? You’1l wear out the carpet like that.
(CATCHES HERSELF, STOPS) Oh! Sorry. I used to be such a patient person. But I seem to have lost the ability to relax, since I began travelling with the Doctor.
I confess I’m anxious too. But I’m sure they will be back [before too long]
(FX: SUDDENLY, FROM OFF, THE FEROCIOUS BARKING OF DOGS, WHICH
ENDS IN A COUPLE OF PAINED YELPS)
That was Portia and Brutus!
Where are they?
In the kitchen, I presume. They sleep in baskets beneath the Sink.
Pass me that poker, Phoebe.
(FX: METALLIC CLINK AS SHE LIFTS POKER FROM COMPANION SET AND
IT OVER) (FRIGHTENED) Why?
There may be trouble. Wait here.
Not on your life! I don’t want to be left here on my own.
(FX: CROSSES TO DOOR AND OPENS IT) Come on then, if you must. But stay behind me.
(FOLLOWING) What if it’s one of Father’s animals? A lion or something? What if it’s in the house?
MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL)
What if it’s something worse? (BEAT; GRIM) Come on.
FX: THEY EXIT. CUT TO:
MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 53

HANNAH: (SCREAMS) Silver Crow! Shoot it! Kill it-!
DOCTOR: No, please-!
SILVER CROW: I cannot get a clear shot —
NATHANIEL: Out of the way, Crow —
NATHANIEL: (FX: THE GORILLA LETS LOOSE A FINAL, EAR-SPLITTING ROAR. NEXT
MOMENT: THERE IS THE TWIN BLAST OF A HUNTING RIFLE AND THE
GORILLA: TOPPLES WITH AN ALMIGHTY THUD. ALL FALLS QUIET)
DOCTOR: I do wish you hadn’t done that, Mr Whitlock.
NATHANIEL: (DISMOUNTING) You’re right. One hundred and fifty pounds, that creature cost.
HECTOR: I’m sorry, Mr Whitlock, sir —
NATHANIEL: Dismount, boy. I said, dismount!
HANNAH: (OFF) Is Mr Tremayne-?
HECTOR: He’s hurt, but not too badly, I think.
EDWIN: Easy for you to say. Gah, my leg! I think it’s broken!
SILVER CROW: (OFF) We should take Mr Tremayne back to the house.
HECTOR: Oh Lord. The gorilla’s not dead.
DOCTOR WHO: MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 47
NATHANIEL: That was an incredibly foolish thing to do, boy, riding your horse between an animal and its prey like that.
HECTOR: Its ‘prey’, as you call it, was my father. What else could I do?
NATHANIEL: (GRUNTS) Yes, well. (FX: PASSING SHOTGUN) Here. Take my gun.
HECTOR: Whatever for?
NATHANIEL: I only wounded the beast.
HECTOR: You mean...?
EDWIN: (SADISTIC) Someone’s got to put it out of its misery.
HECTOR: But I can’t-! Really-!
DOCTOR: (TROTTING OVER) Please, don’t torment the boy!
NATHANIEL: (TO HECTOR) ‘Boy’, exactly. Now, Hector — let’s see the man.
NATHANIEL: (FX: TWO MORE RIFLE BLASTS AS HECTOR FIRES INTO THE GORILLA’S
PRONE: BODY. BEAT. HORSES SNORT)
NATHANIEL: Damned unusual for a gorilla to attack like that, mind.
DOCTOR: No, they’re not usually violent, unless provoked. (A THOUGHT) Or unless — (STOPS SHORT)
HANNAH: Unless what?
DOCTOR: Stand back from the body, Hector. You too, Whitlock.
NATHANIEL: Why? It’s quite [dead.] (SUDDEN SURPRISE) Good Lord!
DOCTOR WHO: MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 48
DOCTOR: Yes, I see it too.
NATHANIEL: Its fur — it’s rippling, like there’s something alive beneath the [skin. ]
NATHANIEL: (FX: FIZZING/CRACKLING OF THE ENERGY-CREATURE ERUPTING FROM
INSIDE: GORILLA)
SILVER CROW: The Tunka!
DOCTOR: The energy-form. Get back, everyone!
HANNAH: Good grief! That creature must have been inside the gorilla! Inside its body.
HECTOR: Doing what?
NATHANIEL: Feeding on it? Like some kind of parasite?
DOCTOR: More likely manipulating its movements.
HECTOR: You mean that thing made the gorilla attack my father?
DOCTOR: I’m afraid so.
NATHANIEL: Which means it’s hostile. (FX: SNATCHING THE GUN BACK OFF HECTOR) Give me the gun back, lad —
DOCTOR: (SHOUTS) Nathaniel, no!
DOCTOR: (FX: TWO RIFLE BLASTS AS NATHANIEL FIRES AT THE ALIEN. THE
BULLETS: PASS THROUGH, HITTING TREES WITH A SPLINTERING OF WOOD. THE CRACKLING, FIZZING GROWS MOMENTARILY LOUDER, ANGRIER, THEN FADES AS THE ALIEN ASCENDS INTO THE TREES)
HANNAH: It’s retreating!
DOCTOR WHO: MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 49
DOCTOR: (SHOUTS) Come back! We want to help you!
HANNAH: It’s gone.
DOCTOR: (ANGRILY) Couldn’t you have kept that trigger finger of yours still even for a second?
NATHANIEL: (ALSO ANGRY) The beast attacked Mr Tremayne!
HECTOR: It could have killed him!
DOCTOR: (CALMING DOWN) I know... I know, I’m sorry. You were very brave, Hector. And you were only doing what you thought was right, Nathaniel. But we’ve already established that bullets have no effect on it. You might as well try killing smoke. By shooting at it, all we’re achieving is cementing the notion that we’re hostile.
SILVER CROW: But is the creature’s attack on Mr Tremayne not proof that it means us harm, Doctor?
DOCTOR: Not necessarily. It could be frightened or confused, lashing out because it thinks that it’s under threat.
EDWIN: Damn it all, Whitlock — I’1l go to law if you don’t get me attention!
HECTOR: We must get my father back to the house.
DOCTOR: Yes. You do that. But I need to get to my... erm, aeroplane. I’ve got some scientific equipment there that will enable me to analyse these crystal samples.
NATHANIEL: Don’t be a fool, man. You can’t go alone.
SILVER CROW: (TROTTING FORWARD) Then I shall accompany the Doctor, to act as his protector.
DOCTOR WHO: MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 50
DOCTOR: There’s really no need.
SILVER CROW: I insist upon it.
NATHANIEL: (CHUCKLES) I’d advise you to comply, Doctor. When Silver Crow gets an idea into his head, there’s no shifting him. He’s the most stubborn fellow I’ve ever met.
DOCTOR: Oh, I wouldn’t be so sure about that, Mr Whitlock. (TAKING REINS) Come on, Silver Crow.
DOCTOR WHO: MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 51
PHOEBE: Nyssa, dear — why don’t you sit by the fire? You’1l wear out the carpet like that.
NYSSA: (CATCHES HERSELF, STOPS) Oh! Sorry. I used to be such a patient person. But I seem to have lost the ability to relax, since I began travelling with the Doctor.
PHOEBE: I confess I’m anxious too. But I’m sure they will be back [before too long]
PHOEBE: (FX: SUDDENLY, FROM OFF, THE FEROCIOUS BARKING OF DOGS, WHICH
ABRUPTLY: ENDS IN A COUPLE OF PAINED YELPS)
PHOEBE: That was Portia and Brutus!
NYSSA: Where are they?
PHOEBE: In the kitchen, I presume. They sleep in baskets beneath the Sink.
NYSSA: Pass me that poker, Phoebe.
PHOEBE: (FX: METALLIC CLINK AS SHE LIFTS POKER FROM COMPANION SET AND
HANDS: IT OVER) (FRIGHTENED) Why?
NYSSA: There may be trouble. Wait here.
PHOEBE: Not on your life! I don’t want to be left here on my own.
NYSSA: (FX: CROSSES TO DOOR AND OPENS IT) Come on then, if you must. But stay behind me.
PHOEBE: (FOLLOWING) What if it’s one of Father’s animals? A lion or something? What if it’s in the house?
DOCTOR WHO: MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL)
DOCTOR WHO: What if it’s something worse? (BEAT; GRIM) Come on.
DOCTOR WHO: 52
DOCTOR WHO: MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 53
DOCTOR: There she is, Silver Crow. In the clearing ahead.
SILVER CROW: I see no aeroplane, Doctor. Only some strange blue box.
DOCTOR: Well, admittedly she’s not a conventional flying machine. She’s rather more... compact.
SILVER CROW: But how-?
DOCTOR: I think you should prepare yourself for something of a shock. (CLICKS TONGUE, TO HORSE) Trot on.
DOCTOR WHO: MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 54
NYSSA: Which way to the kitchen, Phoebe?
PHOEBE: Turn right at the end of this corridor. Then follow the next corridor round to the entrance [hall] —
NYSSA: Ssh! I think I heard something.
PHOEBE: All I can hear is the sound of my own heart, pounding rather too loudly.
NYSSA: Movement, I think. Somewhere ahead of us. Are the dogs secure in the kitchen?
PHOEBE: Father does have a tendency to leave doors open. He likes open Spaces. He always says he hates to feel enclosed in his own home.
NYSSA: So it’s possible that whatever... silenced the dogs could be roaming the house?
PHOEBE: I suppose so. Should we go back?
NYSSA: Do you want to go back?
PHOEBE: Yes.. and no. I’m frightened, but I can’t bear to remain
PHOEBE: ignorant.
NYSSA: Me neither. Let’s carry on. But try not to make any noise.
DOCTOR WHO: MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 55
DOCTOR: (WALKING IN, TO CONSOLE) Come on in, Silver Crow. It’s perfectly safe. (STOPPING) Actually, now I think of it, you'd better bring the horses in too. I’d hate them to end up as a tiger’s breakfast.
SILVER CROW: (STEPPING IN FROM OUTSIDE) The horses? Why are you making fun of [me —] (STOPS ABRUPTLY. STUNNED SILENCE)
DOCTOR: You'll be catching flies in that mouth of yours if you don’t close it.
SILVER CROW: (AWESTRUCK) Nathaniel has opened my eyes to many of Earth’s wonders, Doctor, but nothing I have seen is the equal of this. You are surely a man of magic!
DOCTOR: No such thing. Now I really do think we should bring those horses inside, before they get eaten — hm?
DOCTOR WHO: MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 56
DOCTOR WHO: (FX: FOOTSTEPS CREEPING ON TILED FLOOR — MORE SLOWLY AND
STEALTHILY: THAN BEFORE. AFTER THREE OR FOUR STEPS WE AGAIN HEAR THE TAPPING OF DOG CLAWS — STILL OFF, BUT CLOSER)
PHOEBE: (GASPS, STOPS) Did you-?
NYSSA: (SOTTO) Whatever it is, it’s just round the next corner.
PHOEBE: (SOTTO) What should we do?
NYSSA: (SOTTO) Retreat. But don’t turn your back.
NYSSA: (FX: THE GIRLS SHUFFLE RAPIDLY BACKWARDS. OVER THIS WE HEAR THE RHYTHMIC TAPPING OF CLAWS GETTING CLOSER... AS THE DOG, PORTIA, APPEARS AND BARKS CURTLY)
PHOEBE: (STOPS, RELIEVED) Oh! It’s only Portia!
NYSSA: Thank goodness.
PHOEBE: (RAISING HER VOICE) Here, Portia. It’s only me.
PHOEBE: (SURPRISED) Portia, whatever’s the matter? It’s me. You
PHOEBE: recognise me, don’t you?
NYSSA: (WARNINGLY) Keep back, Phoebe. Don’t get any closer.
PHOEBE: Why not?
NYSSA: Something’s wrong.
DOCTOR WHO: MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 57
PHOEBE: She’s frightened, that’s all. What’s the matter, girl? What’s [ happened? ]
NYSSA: Get back, Phoebe!
PHOEBE: What’s happening to her fur? It’s rippling, standing on end-!
NYSSA: It’s the alien! It’s inside her!
PHOEBE: What?
NYSSA: It’s been using her as a host, but I think it prefers the look
NYSSA: of us. Run!
DOCTOR WHO: MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 58
DOCTOR WHO: (FX: UNEASY CLOPPING AND SNORTING OF THE HORSES. INTERNAL DOOR
OPENS: )
DOCTOR: (ENTERING) All done. How are the horses?
SILVER CROW: They are a little restless, Doctor.
DOCTOR: I wonder if it’s the colour scheme? Bit too much white, perhaps?
SILVER CROW: Did you learn anything more about the moonflesh-creature in your laboratory?
DOCTOR: A little — though not much more than I hadn’t already guessed. In their active state, the crystals break down into a loosely conjoined lattice of electrical [impulses] —
SILVER CROW: These words of yours mean nothing to me.
DOCTOR: No, I don’t suppose they do. Look — think of it like intelligent lightning. A creature composed of pure energy, which has the ability to invade and influence both living and inanimate matter. People, animals, even rocks and plants. If it put its mind to it, our alien friend could possess a tree and use the roots like tentacles, to drag itself along. Or it could create a body for itself out of rock, or even metal.
SILVER CROW: My people believe that spirits dwell in all things, Doctor. Perhaps this moonflesh-creature is merely Takuskanskan come among us.
DOCTOR: Another of your Gods?
DOCTOR: /cont
DOCTOR WHO: MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 59
SILVER CROW: Takuskanskan gives life to all things and makes them move. My people tell a story of a rabbit which came across a clot of blood upon the ground and began to kick it, filling the clot with the spirit of motion. The clot grew hands and eyes, and arms, and a beating heart, and soon it formed itself into a boy. Then Iktome, the trickster, encouraged the tribe to tie up the boy and cut him into pieces and put him into a soup pot. But a storm rose, and a great cloud hid the face of the sun, turning everything into black night, and when the storm passed the pieces of the blood-clot boy were gone.
DOCTOR: Fascinating. You know, it wouldn’t surprise me if your people had encountered these visitors before, Silver Crow — or perhaps even this same one. How did they deal with it, I wonder?
SILVER CROW: Perhaps we too should cut the moonflesh-creature into pieces and put him into a soup pot.
DOCTOR: A little harsh, don’t you think? Besides, we’d have to catch him first.
SILVER CROW: How do you capture lightning, Doctor?
DOCTOR: In a bottle, perhaps? (SIGHS) Come on, we’d better get back to the others.
DOCTOR WHO: MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 60
DOCTOR WHO: (FX: PHOEBE AND NYSSA RUNNING IN FROM CORRIDOR, THE FIZZING
JUST: BEHIND THEM)
PHOEBE: (TO STOP) It’s right behind us!
NYSSA: Out of the way, so I can shut the —
NYSSA: (FX: AS THE FIZZING, CRACKLING OF THE PURSUING ALIEN REACHES A CRESCENDO, THE DRAWING ROOM DOOR SLAMS SHUT WITH A CRASH.
CRACKLING: CONTINUES, MUFFLED BEHIND DOOR, THROUGH: )
PHOEBE: What now?
NYSSA: (HOLDING HERSELF AGAINST DOOR) I can’t hold the door forever. We need something to use as a barricade!
PHOEBE: Oh! (LOOKING ROUND) Er —
NYSSA: (HOLDING DOOR) The long chair, there!
PHOEBE: The chaise-longue?
NYSSA: Whatever it’s called. Quickly, drag it here!
PHOEBE: (EFFORT) (FX: AS SHE DRAGS HEAVY CHAIR A FEW FEET TO DOOR — SCRAPING ON FLOOR) This is no way to treat a William the Fourth —
NYSSA: (HELPING HER MANHANDLE IT INTO PLACE AGAINST THE DOOR) Never mind that. (STEPPING BACK, EXHALING) Well, it’s better than nothing.
NYSSA: (FX: THE FIERCE FIZZING CRACKLE OF THE ALIEN SUDDENLY FADES AND DIES, LIKE A FIREWORK FIZZLING OUT)
PHOEBE: (HUSHED) Has it gone?
DOCTOR WHO: MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 61
NYSSA: I doubt it.
PHOEBE: Then what’s it doing?
NYSSA: Taking stock, perhaps?
NYSSA: (FX: FIZZING CRACKLE OF THE ALIEN AGAIN — LOUDER, AS IT CREEPS
FROM: UNDER THE DOOR)
PHOEBE: (HORRIFIED) Nyssa, look! The red mist! It’s coming under the door!
NYSSA: Oh no. (PULLING PHOEBE) Get back!
NYSSA: (FX: THE FIZZING CRACKLE OF THE ALIEN IS IN THE ROOM WITH THEM NOW. IT SOUNDS ANGRY. THE GIRLS HAVE TO SHOUT TO MAKE THEMSELVES HEARD)
PHOEBE: (TERRIFIED) It’s in here with us! What do we do?
NYSSA: There’s nothing we can do, Phoebe. We’re trapped!
DOCTOR WHO: MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 62
DOCTOR WHO: (FX: FADE UP THUD OF 2 x HORSES ON DRY EARTH/GRASS AS THE DOCTOR AND SILVER CROW RETURN TO THE HOUSE AT A GALLOP)
DOCTOR: (RIDING, BEHIND) Steady on, Silver Crow. I’m not the rider you are!
SILVER CROW: (RIDING, AHEAD) You are doing well, Doctor. And it is not much further to the Manor!
SILVER CROW: (FX: SUDDENLY, A WHISTLING NOISE AND A THUMPING EXPLOSION AS A
SMALL: BUT DENSE METEORITE-LIKE OBJECT FALLS FROM THE SKY AND
EMBEDS: ITSELF INTO THE EARTH. HORSES REAR AND WHINNY IN PANIC)
DOCTOR: (STAYING HORSE) Whoa there! Easy!
SILVER CROW: (ALARMED) Did you see that, Doctor? Something fell from the sky!
DOCTOR: Yes — a projectile of some kind. Perhaps a meteorite?
SILVER CROW: It came down just beyond those trees —
SILVER CROW: (FX: NO SOONER HAS HE SPOKEN THAN, CLOSER STILL, WE HEAR THE WHISTLE-CRUMP OF ANOTHER FALLING OBJECT. MUD SPATTER. AGAIN THE HORSES WHINNY)
SILVER CROW: (STRUGGLING TO KEEP CONTROL OF THE REINS) Steady, boy. (TO DOCTOR) That one was much closer.
DOCTOR: I see it. It’s made a crater. (CLICKING TONGUE) Come on.
DOCTOR: (FX: THEY COAX THE HORSES A FEW FEET TOWARDS THE SECOND FALLEN OBJECT)
SILVER CROW: (AS THEY APPROACH) I do not like this, Doctor. I sense — something bad.
DOCTOR WHO: MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 63
DOCTOR: (PEERING INTO CRATER) I can’t see the bottom. Whatever it was came down, it’s buried itself deep into the earth.
SILVER CROW: There, Doctor, look! Rising from the darkness. Red mist!
DOCTOR: Oh, no!
DOCTOR: (FX: AT HIS WORDS WE HEAR ANOTHER WHISTLE-CRUMP OF A FALLING PROJECTILE... AND ANOTHER... AND ANOTHER... AND ANOTHER! )
SILVER CROW: (LOUD, OVER NOISE) More of them! Coming down like rain!
DOCTOR: Yes. I’m afraid our problem has escalated.
DOCTOR: END OF PART TWO
DOCTOR WHO: MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 64

elements.text: PART THREE
REPRISE:
(FX: .. WHISTLE-CRUMP OF A FALLING PROJECTILE... AND ANOTHER... AND
ANOTHER... AND ANOTHER! )
(LOUD, OVER NOISE) More of them! Coming down like rain!
Yes. I’m afraid our problem has escalated.
27. INT. ENTRANCE HALL
(FX: MAIN DOORS BURST OPEN. NATHANIEL LEADS; HECTOR AND HANNAH
INJURED EDWIN INTO THE HOUSE)
That’s it. Bring him inside. Soon get you comfortable, old boy.
(FX: HECTOR AND HANNAH ACCIDENTALLY BUMP EDWIN’S LEG AGAINST THE WALL)
(CRIES OUT IN PAIN) Gah, me leg! Watch what you’re doing, you idiot boy!
Sorry, Father. It’s rather a narrow entranceway.
Where to, Mr Whitlock?
The drawing room. Nice and warm in there. Get Phoebe to make you some hot beef tea, eh, Tremayne?
Sooner have a brandy.
Well, I’m sure we can rustle up both. (SHOUTING) Phoebe? Phoebe? (AFTER A PAUSE) Odd. Where’s she got to?
Perhaps she and Miss Nyssa are upstairs?
No doubt embroiled in some girlish pursuit or other.
MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 65
(SARCASTICALLY) I expect they’re combing one another’s hair or admiring the lace edgings on the coverlets. Such empty-headed creatures women [are.]
FX: DISTANT WHISTLE/CRUMP OF FALLING PROJECTILE
What on Earth...?
Are you going to stand there like a ninny? I’m in pain, boy!
Please, Father. I thought I heard something outside —
FX: ANOTHER WHISTLE/CRUMP
There it is again!
MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 66
28. EXT. GROUNDS OF WHITLOCK MANOR — OPEN LAND
FX: MORE FALLING PROJECTILES
NB: BOTH MEN RAISING VOICES OVER THE SOUND
Perhaps Wakan Tanka is angry, Doctor. It sends more of the moon’s living flesh to punish us.
I rather think these visitors have travelled a little further than the moon, Silver Crow. Nonetheless, I fear you may be right.
How so?
If the original creature was merely an advance guard, this could be an invasion force.
(FX: THE WHISTLE-CRUMP OF A FALLING PROJECTILE, CLOSE ENOUGH FOR THE MEN TO BE SHOWERED IN PATTERING MUD. THE HORSES WHINNY/SNORT/STAMP IN FRIGHT)
It’s getting rather perilous out here. We should get back to the house.
Ya! Yaa!
FX: THEY GATHER HORSES AND GALLOP OFF. FADE TO:
MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 67
29. INT. DRAWING ROOM
FX: FADE UP CRACKLING FIRE. DISTANT WHISTLE-CRUMP
Not so frequent now.
Are we under attack? Mr Whitlock?
Goodness only knows, boy.
I do hope the Doctor is safe. And Silver Crow.
Oh, Silver Crow knows how to take care of himself.
GROANS THEATRICALLY
How are you, Father?
(IN PAIN) My leg... it hurts so much...
I’m sure it does, Mr Tremayne. It is broken, after all. But I’m afraid you must grin and bear it for now. As soon as this bombardment [ceases] —
(INTERRUPTING; STILL IN PAIN BUT ANGRY) Grin and bear it, be damned! I need a doctor, woman! Immediately!
For goodness’ sake, stop bleating, man! Can’t you see that everyone’s doing their bit?
(OUTRAGED) No, sir! No, I cannot! All I see is that I’m being denied the medical assistance that I so desperately need.
(PLACATORY) Father, please —
Dear Lord. Ms Bartholomew — give the man another brandy. (ASIDE) And if that doesn’t work, gag the blighter.
MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 68
STIFLES LAUGHTER
I heard that, sir! How dare you, sir!

(LOSING HIS TEMPER) But I do dare, sir! On my travels around the globe I have met pompous potentates, knavish kings and rotten regents aplenty. But never, sir, never have I met such a self-pitying, self-aggrandizing example of humanity as you!
(PLACATORY) I say there, Mr Whitlock-
FX: DOCTOR'S FOOTSTEPS APPROACHING DOWN CORRIDOR THROUGH:
(FURIOUS) If I was not incapacitated, sir, I would thrash the shirt from your back, sir!
(EQUALLY FURIOUS) I dearly wish that you were not incapacitated, sir, for I should like to see [you try!]
FX: DOOR OPENS
(ENTERING) Is this a private argument or can anyone join in?
(RELIEF) Doctor. You’re back!
So it would seem. Do carry on, don’t mind me.
Silver Crow, man — where is he?
Bedding down the horses. They’ve had rather a trying time. (BEAT AS HE LOOKS AROUND) Where’s Nyssa?
Upstairs. We think.
Think-?
As a matter of fact, we’re not entirely [sure] —
MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 69
CALLING FROM OFF, APPROACHING RAPIDLY ALONG THE CORRIDOR
Doctor! At last!
Oh, but here comes Miss Nyssa now!
Ah, Nyssa. Thank goodness — (SUDDEN CONCERN AS HE TAKES IN HER APPEARANCE) Are you all right? You look a little flustered.
I’m fine, Doctor. It’s Phoebe I’m concerned about —
(SNAPS) Why? What’s happened to my daughter? Speak, girl!
Phoebe’s in rather a.. delicate state. I think perhaps the Doctor should speak to her. Alone.
Don’t be ridiculous. If anyone’s going to speak to her, it’s me. —
No. I think the Doctor would be better qualified.
You’re saying it’s a medical matter?
Er... yes. Phoebe’s been rather... overcome.
In all the excitement, you mean? Well, why didn’t you say so, child? Nerves, I expect. Her mother was a martyr to the vapours.
Doctor?
Yes, I’ll come at once.
Please give Miss Phoebe my regards. Tell her that I hope she feels better soon.
I will.
MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 70
Just a moment! I’ve broken a leg, sir. I think that makes me a little more deserving of medical attention than a girl with an attack of hysterics.
Well, rest assured, I’1ll be back soon, Mr Tremayne. In the meantime, keep yourself warm and drink plenty of liquids. (SWEEPING OUT, NYSSA FOLLOWING) Come along, Nyssa!
FX: DOOR CLOSES FIRMLY BEHIND
(OUTRAGED) Well, of all the...
You heard what the Doctor said, Mr Tremayne. Plenty of liquids. In fact. I think we could all do with a nice cup of tea — Mr Whitlock?
(SURPRISED) Who? Me?
It is your house. And we have all paid for full board.
Yes, but that’s not to say —
Tell you what, sir. I’1ll give you a hand.
Oh, very well. But it’s come to a pretty pass when a chap is required to act as housemaid in his own home.
The world is changing, Mr Whitlock. It’s the new way of things.
In Bohemia, perhaps. Never in Suffolk. (FX: OPENS DOOR) Come on, boy. (EXITS, HECTOR FOLLOWING)
MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 71
30. INT. STAIRS TO UPSTAIRS LANDING
FX: DOCTOR'S AND NYSSA’S HURRIED FOOTSTEPS ON WOODEN STAIRS
(CONTINUING A CONVERSATION) .. The energy-creature enveloped Phoebe and then simply passed into her, through her skin.
But she hasn’t been harmed?
Not as far as I can tell. And if the alien is controlling her, then it’s made no attempt to harm me either.
Well, that’s an encouraging sign. (FX: FOOTSTEPS HALT AS THEY REACH THE TOP OF THE STAIRS) So what has it been doing?

Nothing. Once Phoebe had absorbed the energy she simply stood there for several minutes, staring into space. I tried to speak to her, but she didn’t respond. Then eventually she walked upstairs and went into her bedroom.
Acclimatising perhaps. Human brains are a bit more complex than gorillas’. This is the room?
It is.
(FX: DOCTOR TURNS DOORKNOB AND PUSHES THE DOOR OPEN WITH A
MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 72
31. INT. UPSTAIRS BEDROOM [CONTINUOUS]
FX: GENTLE HISSING, CRACKLING OF THE ALIEN
(ENTERS ROOM CAUTIOUSLY) Hello there. I’m the Doctor. I think you already know my friend, Nyssa. (MOVING FORWARD) Do you mind if we come in?
(FOLLOWING) We won’t get too close, if you don’t want us to.

I’1l just sit here on the edge of the bed, if that’s alright-? (FX: CREAK OF BEDSPRINGS) There, that’s better. Now — what say we have a little chat, just the three of us? I know that you can use Phoebe’s vocal cords - that’s the name of the person you’ve possessed, by the way. Phoebe. Nice girl. Gentle, compassionate... Do you understand compassion? I’m sure you do. Intelligent being like you.
BEAT.
Must say, you’re not really giving us much to go on here.
Are you scared? Did you arrive here by accident, perhaps? If so, there’s no need to worry. We can get you home if that’s what you want.
Yes, absolutely. (A THOUGHT) Or maybe that’s why your friends are here-?
(TO DOCTOR) You mean there are more of them?
I’m afraid so. (TO ALIEN) Is that? Have they come to collect you. Should we let them know you’re [here?]
PHOEBE/ALIEN:
FX: VOICE DEEPER, TREATED WITH A HISSING, CRACKLING EFFECT
No.
So you do speak! Splendid.
Do you have a name? Something we can call you?
MOONFLESH by Mark Morris (FINAL) 73 PHOEBE/ALIEN:
I am Vatuus. (NB: ‘VA-TOOS’ )
Delighted to meet you, Vatuus. So, these new arrivals — I take it that they’re not your friends?
PHOEBE/ALIEN: They are... assassins.
I see.
